questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

Owl's eye appearance on urinary examination is typically seen in Cytomegalovirus.

 

CMV, Human Herpes Virus 5, Largest virus in Herpesviridae family

 

 

 

Other options are not associated with Owl’s eye appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: What is the maximum score that can be achieved in the New Ballard Score? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 50 

 

Explanation: 

 

The New Ballard Score (also called the Expanded New Ballard Score) is a clinical assessment tool used to determine gestational age in newborns. It evaluates both neuromuscular and physical maturity criteria. The score consists of six neuromuscular criteria (posture, square window, arm recoil, popliteal angle, scarf sign, and heel to ear) and six physical maturity criteria (skin, lanugo, plantar surface, breast, eye/ear, and genitalia). A total possible range is from -10 to +50 points. Thus, the maximum achievable score is 50, which corresponds to a gestational age of approximately 44 weeks.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 30 - Incorrect. This is below the maximum possible score. A score of 30 would correspond to a gestational age of approximately 36-38 weeks.

 

Option B. 40 - Incorrect. This is below the maximum possible score. A score of 40 would correspond to a gestational age of approximately 40-42 weeks.

 

Option D. 60 - Incorrect. This exceeds the maximum possible score for the New Ballard Score. The highest possible score is 50 points.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The New Ballard Score has a maximum value of 50 points, which corresponds to a post-term infant of approximately 44 weeks gestational age. This scoring system allows for assessment of premature infants as young as 20 weeks gestational age (score of -10).

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Barium meal

 

Explanation:

 

The given image is a barium meal. This study is used to examine the stomach and proximal duodenum.

 

Visual Cues: The image shows the distribution of barium within the stomach, outlining its contours and revealing its internal structure, which is typical in a barium meal examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barium Swallow: This study primarily evaluates the esophagus and does not extend into the stomach. The radiograph showing the stomach filled with barium indicates that the procedure goes beyond just a barium swallow.

 

Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through: This investigation involves not only the stomach but also a sequential imaging of the small intestine as the barium passes through. The specific image provided does not show barium beyond the proximal duodenum, which is typical in a simple barium meal.

 

Option D. Barium Enema: This procedure is used to visualize the large intestine (colon) and rectum using barium introduced via the rectum. The provided image showing the stomach filled with barium clearly indicates that it's not a barium enema.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient has an urge to urinate but he is not able to do. He has history of a fall astride injury. On examination blood is seen at meatus. Which of the following injury is most common? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulbar urethra rupture

 

A patient with a fall astride injury, presenting with an inability to urinate and blood at the urethral meatus, strongly suggests a bulbar urethral rupture. The bulbar urethra is the most commonly injured part of the urethra in straddle injuries, which occur due to forceful compression against the pubic symphysis (e.g., falling onto a hard object like a bicycle crossbar or a beam).

 

  • The bulbar urethra is located within the superficial perineal pouch, and when it ruptures, urine and blood can accumulate in the superficial perineal space, leading to perineal swelling and hematoma.
  • Blood at the meatus is a classical sign of anterior urethral injury, which is often associated with bulbar urethral trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Membranous urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • The membranous urethra is commonly injured in pelvic fractures (e.g., motor vehicle accidents), not in straddle injuries. It is located in the deep perineal pouch, and its rupture leads to urine accumulation in the deep perineal space and retropubic space.
  • Patients with membranous urethral injuries often present with high-riding prostate on rectal examination, which is absent in this case.

 

Option C. Extraperitoneal urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • Extraperitoneal urethral rupture usually occurs with pelvic fractures, affecting the posterior urethra (prostatic or membranous urethra).
  • It leads to urine extravasation around the bladder, visible as fluid collection in the retropubic space on imaging.

 

Option D. Intraperitoneal urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • Intraperitoneal rupture typically refers to bladder rupture, not urethral injury.
  • It occurs due to a direct blow to a full bladder, leading to urine leakage into the peritoneal cavity, which presents with peritonitis symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethral rupture is the most common site of urethral injury in straddle injuries, presenting with blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma, and urinary retention.

questions.text: A person had a fall on an outstretched hand. He presented with pain and swelling at the base of the thumb. Which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scaphoid

 

The scaphoid bone is one of the carpal bones located in the wrist and forms the floor of the anatomical snuffbox, which is an important surface landmark on the dorsum of the hand. When a person falls on an outstretched hand, the force is transmitted through the thumb to the wrist, often resulting in a fracture of the scaphoid bone. This type of injury is common and is characterized by pain and tenderness at the base of the thumb, specifically in the anatomical snuffbox region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lunate: The lunate is another carpal bone located more centrally in the wrist. Although it can be injured in falls, it is more commonly associated with dislocations rather than fractures when compared to the scaphoid, and it does not typically present with pain specifically at the base of the thumb.

 

Option B. Pisiform: The pisiform is a small, pea-shaped carpal bone situated on the anterior (palmar) side of the wrist. It is not commonly involved in injuries related to falls on an outstretched hand, especially when pain and swelling are localized to the base of the thumb.

 

Option D. Trapezium: The trapezium is a carpal bone located just distal to the scaphoid and is involved in articulating with the first metacarpal bone of the thumb. However, it is less likely to be the primary bone injured in a fall on an outstretched hand, as the scaphoid is more susceptible to fractures in such scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scaphoid bone is the most common carpal bone injured in falls on an outstretched hand, especially when the patient presents with pain and swelling at the base of the thumb.

questions.text: Baroreceptors are associated with which vessel? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Internal carotid artery

 

Explanation:


Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the walls of blood vessels that monitor blood pressure. The carotid sinus is a small dilation of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid into external and internal carotid branches. These baroreceptors are specifically located in the adventitial layer of the vessel wall within this dilation. They sense changes in arterial pressure and transmit this information via the carotid sinus nerve (branch of glossopharyngeal nerve) to the medulla.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. External carotid artery: Baroreceptors are not located in the external carotid artery. They are specifically found in the carotid sinus, which is a dilation at the beginning of the internal carotid artery.
  • Option c. Subclavian artery: No baroreceptors are documented in the subclavian artery. The main locations of baroreceptors are the carotid sinus and the aortic arch.
  • Option d. Brachiocephalic trunk: While this vessel branches off the aortic arch, it is not specifically identified as containing baroreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are primarily located in two key areas: the carotid sinus (a dilation of the internal carotid artery) and the aortic arch. These pressure sensors are crucial for the short-term regulation of blood pressure via the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a two-week history of headache, fever, and neck stiffness. His cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows increased opening pressure and positive India ink staining for encapsulated yeast. What is the recommended treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amphotericin B (AMB) + Flucytosine

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings are consistent with cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. The positive India ink staining revealing encapsulated yeast cells is diagnostic. For complicated cases involving CNS infection, the recommended first-line treatment is combination therapy with Amphotericin B and Flucytosine. This combination provides synergistic antifungal activity and better penetration into the CNS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: While fluconazole can be used for uncomplicated cryptococcal infections or as maintenance therapy, it is not the first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option B. Amphotericin B: Although effective, monotherapy with Amphotericin B is less effective than combination therapy.

 

Option D. Fluconazole + Amphotericin B: This combination is not the standard recommended therapy for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The recommended first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis is combination therapy with Amphotericin B and Flucytosine.

questions.text: A Patient after head trauma is opening eyes to verbal commands, localizing pain and is confused. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12

Explanation:

Glasgow Coma Scale calculation:

Eye Opening (E): Opening to verbal commands = 3 points

Motor Response (M): Localizing pain = 5 points

Verbal Response (V): Confused = 4 points

Total GCS = E(3) + M(5) + V(4) = 12 points

Educational Objective:

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HSV2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:


HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

choices.text: HLA B27 is associated in 90% cases
It is non-erosive and only joints are affected
Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign
Affects males more than females

questions.text: All are true about Ankylosing spondylitis except:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is non-erosive and only joints are affected

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by erosive changes.  
  • AS is not completely non-erosive.
  • Over time, inflammation can lead to erosive changes, especially in the sacroiliac joints and the spine.
  • The inflammatory process in AS often leads to erosion of the vertebrae and the formation of syndesmophyte (bone spurs), which contribute to the fusion of spinal segments.
  • While AS primarily affects the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), it can also involve other structures.
  • Extra-articular manifestations can include enthesitis (inflammation of the sites where tendons and ligaments attach to bone), uveitis (eye inflammation), and in some cases, systemic symptoms like fatigue and anemia.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HLA-B27 is associated in 90% of cases: HLA-B27 is a genetic marker that is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Approximately 90% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis test positive for the HLA-B27 antigen. However, not all individuals with this antigen will develop the disease, and not all AS patients will test positive for HLA-B27. The exact role of HLA-B27 in the pathogenesis of AS is not fully understood, but it is considered a significant genetic risk factor. HLA-B27 positivity is used as part of the diagnostic process and can help in predicting the likelihood of AS in patients with symptoms.

 

Option C. Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign: Sacroiliac joint involvement is often one of the earliest signs of ankylosing spondylitis. The sacroiliac joints are typically among the first to be affected in AS. Early symptoms include lower back pain and stiffness that improves with activity and worsens with rest. X-rays or MRI of the sacroiliac joints can reveal characteristic changes associated with AS, such as sacroiliitis (inflammation of the sacroiliac joints) and eventually, structural changes such as joint fusion.

 

 

Option D. Affects males more than females: Ankylosing spondylitis is more common in males than females. Studies suggest that the male-to-female ratio for AS is approximately 2:1 to 3:1. The disease may present differently in women, sometimes leading to a delay in diagnosis. Women with AS might have a less pronounced spinal involvement and more peripheral joint symptoms compared to men.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is an erosive inflammatory condition in which axial skeleton particularly in the spine and sacroiliac joints and other organs are affected.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in OPD with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid tumor

 

  • The given clinical scenario and image points to a diagnosis of parotid tumor.
  • MC benign parotid tumor is Pleomorphic Adenoma.
  • MC site: superficial lobe of parotid

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst: Seen in children at lines of mesodermal fusion like outer canthus of eye.

 

 

Option C. Sebaceous cyst: Will show soft consistency and punctum.

 

 

Option D. Swollen cervical lymph node – will show firm consistency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A parotid tumor, particularly pleomorphic adenoma, is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.
  • It is characterized by slow growth, a variable consistency, and mobility, commonly found in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland.
  • Proper diagnosis involves imaging and FNAC, with treatment typically involving surgical removal while preserving the facial nerve if possible.

questions.text: In the presence of elevated ADH levels, which part of the renal tubule reabsorbs the most water? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Proximal tubule

 

Explanation: 

 

The proximal tubule reabsorbs the largest percentage of filtered water (60-70%) even in the presence of ADH (vasopressin). This represents obligatory H₂O reabsorption that occurs regardless of hormonal status. The Loop of Henle handles 10-15% of water reabsorption, while the distal tubule and collecting ducts account for the remaining reabsorption, which is regulated by ADH as facultative H₂O reabsorption.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Loop of Henle - Only reabsorbs 10-15% of filtered water, significantly less than the proximal tubule. Water reabsorption here occurs primarily in the descending limb due to the presence of aquaporin-1 channels.
  • Option C. Distal tubule - Reabsorbs only 1-3% of water without ADH and up to 10-15% with ADH, still considerably less than the proximal tubule.
  • Option D. Collecting duct - While ADH has its most significant effect here (making it critical for concentrating urine), the absolute amount of water reabsorbed is less than in the proximal tubule. Approximately 14.7% total water reabsorption occurs in the collecting ducts (10% in cortical + 4.7% in medullary collecting ducts).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The proximal tubule performs the majority of water reabsorption (60-70%) through obligatory mechanisms independent of ADH, while ADH primarily regulates the facultative water reabsorption in the distal segments of the nephron.

questions.text: International health agency - DANIDA is supporting which health program of India? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blindness

 

DANIDA (Danish International Development Agency) supports the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI) in India. This international collaboration helps strengthen India's efforts to prevent and control blindness through various initiatives and interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: Incorrect. TB program in India is supported by SIDA (Swedish International Development Agency), not DANIDA.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect. Malaria control is part of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) and does not receive specific support from DANIDA.

 

Option D. Vector-borne diseases: Incorrect. Vector-borne diseases are covered under NVBDCP and do not receive specific support from DANIDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DANIDA (Danish International Development Agency) provides support specifically to India's National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following pathology is shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The image provided shows a typical sign of free air under the right dome of the diaphragm. This finding is highly indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. When there is a perforation in any part of the gastrointestinal tract, air can escape into the peritoneal cavity. This air then rises to the highest point in the abdomen when the patient is in an upright position, which is under the diaphragm, and is visible on an upright chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subacute intestinal obstruction: This condition would not present with free air under the diaphragm. Instead, it would typically show dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Paralytic ileus would also not present with free air under the diaphragm. It usually shows diffusely dilated bowel loops without a transition point on imaging studies.

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: A pleural effusion involves fluid accumulation in the pleural cavity and would not present with air under the diaphragm. It typically shows fluid in the pleural space on a chest X-ray, often blurring the costophrenic angle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray is a classic radiographic finding indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. This is a critical sign that should prompt immediate medical evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: Which feature is not characteristic of an antemortem blood clot? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Chicken Fat Appearance

 

Explanation:

 

Explanation: Chicken fat appearance is not characteristic of antemortem blood clots. This appearance is typically associated with postmortem clots, which tend to have yellow "chicken fat" appearance due to separation of plasma and red cells after death. Antemortem blood clots form during life and have distinguishing features that separate them from postmortem clots.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Laminated - This is a characteristic feature of antemortem blood clots. They show lamination or layering due to the sequential deposition of blood elements as the clot forms during active circulation.

 

Option B. Rubber and Firm - Antemortem clots are rubbery and firm in consistency due to the organized fibrin network that forms during the clotting process while the person is alive.

 

Option D. Contains Platelets - Antemortem clots contain platelets as these blood cells actively participate in clot formation during life. Platelets aggregate and form the initial hemostatic plug in the clotting process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antemortem blood clots (formed during life) are distinguished from postmortem clots by their laminated structure, rubbery/firm consistency, and presence of platelets. The "chicken fat" appearance with separation into two layers is characteristic of postmortem clots, not antemortem ones.

questions.text: Following are mature defense mechanisms, EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Denial

 

Explanation:

 

Denial is classified as an immature defense mechanism, not a mature one. It involves the refusal to accept reality or facts, thereby protecting the individual from experiencing painful emotions or external threats. While it may offer short-term emotional relief, over time it can impair functioning by distorting reality and preventing adaptive coping.

 

In contrast, mature defense mechanisms are considered healthy and adaptive ways of managing internal conflict and stress. They help individuals handle difficult emotions without distorting reality or harming others.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Altruism: It’s a mature defense mechanism.
  • Option B. Humor: It’s a mature defense mechanism.
  • Option C. Anticipation: It’s a mature defense mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:


Defense mechanisms lie on a spectrum from immature to mature. The following are mature defense mechanisms-

  1. Sublimation: Transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse into socially acceptable behaviour. E.g. A middle-aged man with unacceptable sexual desire becomes a painter and starts making nude paintings
  2. Anticipation: Preparing in advance for an unpleasant situation. E.g. A student plans all his arguments comprehensively before telling his father about a bad exam result.
  3. Humour: Use of comedy to deal with an unpleasant situation. E.g  Two medical students joked and laughed at themselves after getting humiliated by the examiner during the viva
  4. Altruism: Use of a social cause to deal with own emotions. E.g. After losing his son in an accident while driving drunk, a man launched an anti-drunk driving campaign, educating others about the dangers of driving under the influence.
  5. Suppression: A voluntary decision not to think about an event for some time and avoid the accompanying emotions. E.g. A highly stressed medical student, facing an upcoming entrance exam, chooses to take a one-day break and doesnt think about the exam at all. It is the only voluntary/conscious defense mechanism

choices.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1
A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin
A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH): Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.

 

B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH): GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.

 

C. Growth Hormone (GH): GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.

 

D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1): IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.

 

The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

choices.text: Basal stent placement

questions.text: Interventional technique used for the management of cerebral aneurysm: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coiling

 

The management of cerebral aneurysms, particularly berry aneurysms, involves two primary interventional techniques: clipping and coiling.

 

  • Coiling: This is an endovascular procedure where a catheter is inserted through the femoral artery and navigated to the aneurysm. Coils are then deployed into the aneurysm to induce thrombosis and prevent rupture. Coiling has lower morbidity and mortality rates compared to surgical clipping and is preferred if the aneurysm is accessible for endovascular treatment.
  • Clipping: This involves a craniotomy where the skull is opened, and a clip is placed at the neck of the aneurysm to isolate it from the circulation. While effective, it is more invasive compared to coiling.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Embolization: While embolization is used in various vascular interventions, it is not the preferred technique for managing cerebral aneurysms.

 

Option C. Basal stent placement: Stents may be used as an adjunct to coiling to support the coil mass and ensure complete occlusion of the aneurysm, but stent placement alone is not effective for managing aneurysms.

 

Option D. Balloon Angioplasty: This technique is used to dilate narrowed blood vessels but is not suitable for treating aneurysms as it can worsen the aneurysm by increasing the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred interventional technique for the management of cerebral aneurysms is endovascular coiling due to its lower morbidity and mortality compared to surgical clipping.

questions.text: Infections of the middle ear can extend to the brain through all of the following routes, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spread through Lymphatic Channels

 

Explanation:

 

Middle ear infections do not spread to the brain through lymphatic channels because there are no lymphatic connections between the middle ear and intracranial structures. The brain and cranial cavity lack a traditional lymphatic system. Infection from the middle ear to the brain occurs through other routes including direct bone erosion, preformed pathways, or hematogenous spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Bony Invasion: This is a common route of intracranial spread of middle ear infection. Cholesteatoma or chronic infection can erode the tegmen tympani (roof of middle ear), allowing infection to spread to the middle cranial fossa causing extradural or subdural abscess. Similarly, erosion of the posterior wall can lead to cerebellar abscess.

 

Option B. Oval or Round Window: These are preformed pathways through which infection can spread from the middle ear to the inner ear (labyrinthitis), and then to the internal auditory canal and cerebellopontine angle through the cochlear aqueduct or internal auditory canal. The subarachnoid space can be accessed through the cochlear aqueduct, which connects the scala tympani with the subarachnoid space.

 

Option C. Spread via Bloodstream: Hematogenous spread is another valid route where infection spreads through venous channels, particularly through emissary veins or by thrombophlebitis of the sigmoid sinus. This can lead to lateral sinus thrombosis, meningitis, or brain abscess.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While middle ear infections can spread to intracranial structures through direct bone erosion, preformed pathways (oval/round windows), and bloodstream, there is no lymphatic route for such spread since the brain lacks traditional lymphatics.

questions.text: At 6 weeks of life, a child developed a fever after DPT vaccination. And now child is 10 weeks due for vaccination. What should be done next? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give DPT Vaccination

 

  • Fever following a DPT vaccination does not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. The child should receive the next scheduled DPT vaccination unless there are specific contraindications or severe adverse reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give DT: Giving only DT (Diphtheria and Tetanus) without the pertussis component may not be ideal for overall protection against these diseases. It's important to provide the complete vaccination schedule, including DPT, unless contraindications exist.

 

Option C. Don’t give DPT: This may not be the best course of action. Fever following the initial DPT vaccination is not an absolute contraindication to subsequent doses. The child should continue the vaccination schedule unless there are specific contraindications.

 

Option D. Don’t give any vaccination: This is not the recommended approach. Missing or delaying vaccinations may leave the child susceptible to vaccine-preventable diseases. It's important to adhere to the recommended vaccination schedule whenever possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the approach to managing adverse events following immunization. Recognize that mild reactions, such as fever after a vaccine, do not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. Adherence to the recommended vaccination schedule is crucial for providing timely and effective protection against vaccine-preventable diseases

questions.text: Apocrine glands are present in which of the following?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Axilla

 

 

 

Apocrine glands are a type of sweat gland that are primarily found in certain areas of the body. These glands release their secretions in response to emotional stress or hormonal changes. They are different from the more common eccrine sweat glands, which are distributed throughout most of the body and are primarily involved in temperature regulation.

 

  • Axilla: Apocrine glands are predominantly located in the axilla (underarm) region. They become active during puberty and release a thicker, milky secretion that can produce body odor when broken down by skin bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face: The face contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, but not apocrine glands.

 

Option B. Scalp: The scalp contains numerous sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, but apocrine glands are not typically found in this area.

 

Option C. Palms and soles: The palms and soles have a high concentration of eccrine sweat glands, which are crucial for thermoregulation. Apocrine glands are not found in these regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apocrine glands are primarily found in the axilla (underarm) region and become active during puberty, releasing thicker secretions that can lead to body odor when metabolized by skin bacteria.

questions.text: Which secondary ossification center of the femur is the first to fuse with the shaft? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Lesser trochanter

 

The lesser trochanter is the first secondary ossification center of the femur to fuse with the shaft. This traction epiphysis appears between 13-14 years and fuses with the shaft by 16-17 years. The lesser trochanter is a nonarticular traction epiphysis that provides attachment to the iliopsoas muscle, which exerts a pulling force on this bony projection during muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Greater trochanter - The greater trochanter is also a traction epiphysis (provides attachment to muscles like gluteus medius), but it appears at 4 years and fuses with the shaft around 17-18 years, after the lesser trochanter has already fused.

 

Option C. Femoral head - The femoral head is a pressure epiphysis that appears at 1 year and fuses with the shaft by 18-19 years. Being articular, it's involved in weight transmission at the hip joint.

 

Option D. Distal end - The distal end of the femur is the first secondary ossification center to appear (around birth), but it's the last to fuse with the shaft (around 18-20 years). It's a pressure epiphysis that transmits weight at the knee joint.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Traction epiphyses (like the lesser trochanter) generally fuse earlier than pressure epiphyses (like the femoral head and distal end), with the lesser trochanter being the first secondary ossification center of the femur to fuse with the shaft.

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergilloma

 

The patient has a history of tuberculosis and now presents with hemoptysis. The chest X-ray shows a cavity with a mass inside it, which is suggestive of an aspergilloma, also known as a fungal ball.

 

Aspergilloma typically forms in pre-existing lung cavities caused by conditions such as tuberculosis. The fungal ball is composed of Aspergillus organisms and debris, and it often presents as a crescent-shaped shadow known as Monod's sign, although this may not always be clearly visible.

 

Most patients with aspergilloma are asymptomatic, but when symptoms do occur, hemoptysis is the most common presenting symptom, ranging from mild to life-threatening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic cancer: While bronchogenic cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma, can present with cavitating lesions, it is less likely in this case given the patient's history of TB and the appearance of the cavity with a mass, which is more typical of aspergilloma.

 

Option C. Lung abscess: Lung abscesses also present as cavitating lesions, but they typically show air-fluid levels on imaging, which are not evident in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic cyst: Bronchogenic cysts have a completely different radiographic appearance and clinical presentation. They are typically congenital and do not present as cavitating lesions with a mass inside them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in pre-existing lung cavities from conditions such as tuberculosis. It presents as a cavity with a fungal ball inside and can cause hemoptysis, which may be severe.

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Histamine 

 

Histamine is involved in the mediation of inflammatory vascular events rather than fever.

 

Fever is defined by an increase in body temperature of 1° to 4°C. It is a prominent manifestation of the acute-phase response, particularly when associated with infection.

 

Pyrogens are substances that cause fever. They can be either exogenous or endogenous.

 

  • Endogenous progens include IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
  • Exogenous pyrogens are bacterial lipopolysaccharides that stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous progens (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Cytokines increase the activity of cyclooxygenases, which convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. These prostaglandins are produced in the hypothalamic vascular and perivascular cells. They stimulate the production of neurotransmitters in the hypothalamus, which raises the temperature setpoint. This is especially true of PGE2.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. IL-1, B. Prostaglandins and C. TNF: These are all endogenous pyrogens that directly contribute to the fever response by influencing the temperature regulation in the hypothalamus and stimulating the production of prostaglandins that raise the body’s temperature setpoint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is involved in mediating the local vascular effects of inflammation and not in the fever response, which is primarily driven by IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
